qas.question: What value of some capacitors decreases with age?
What causes the decrease of capacitance in ceramic capacitors as they age?
What is one of the most important aging factors in capacitors?
What is another important factor which governs how a capacitor ages?
At what point can the aging effect of a capacitor be reversed if the component is heated beyond?
What value of some capacitors increases with age?
What causes the increase of capacitance in ceramic capacitors as they age?
What is one of the least important aging factors in capacitors?
What is the least important factor which governs how a capacitor ages?
At what point can the aging effect of a capacitor never be reversed if the component is heated beyond?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>The capacitance<b5_0/><a0_0/> of certain capacitors decreases as the component ages. In ceramic capacitors, this is caused by <a1_0><b6_0>degradation of the dielectric<b6_0/><a1_0/>. <a2_0><b7_0>The type of dielectric<b7_0/><a2_0/>, <a3_0><b8_0>ambient operating and storage temperatures<b8_0/><a3_0/> are the most significant aging factors, while the operating voltage has a smaller effect. The aging process may be reversed by heating the component above <a4_0><b9_0>the Curie point<b9_0/><a4_0/>. Aging is fastest near the beginning of life of the component, and the device stabilizes over time. Electrolytic capacitors age as the electrolyte evaporates. In contrast with ceramic capacitors, this occurs towards the end of life of the component.
